doc.after: Tens of thousands filled the streets across Egypt on Friday, 28Â January,[20] called by some the "Friday of Anger" (Arabic: Ø¬ÙØ¹Ø© Ø§ÙØºØ¶Ø¨â Ç§umÊ¿at al-Ä¡aá¸ab Egyptian Arabic:Â [ËÉ¡omÊet elËÉ£ÉdÉb])[21] and by others as the "Day of Rage".[22][23] Shortly before 1:00Â am, hours ahead of the protests, the Egyptian government shut down Internet services,[24][25][26] although some people communicated using a text-to-speech telephone service set up by Google and Twitter.[27] Text messaging and mobile phone services also appeared to be blocked.[28] According to Vodafone, all mobile operators in Egypt were instructed to suspend services in selected areas. The authorities had prior legislative approval to issue such an order.[29]
